Harnack's inequality

Let Ω⊆C\Omega \subseteq \CΩ⊆C be a connected open set, let z0∈Ωz_0 \in \Omegaz0​∈Ω, and let U\mathcal{U}U be the set of positive harmonic functions UUU on Ω\OmegaΩ such that U(z0)=1U\p{z_0} = 1U(z0​)=1. Prove that for every compact set K⊆ΩK \subseteq \OmegaK⊆Ω there is a finite constant MMM (depending on Ω\OmegaΩ, z0z_0z0​, and KKK) such that

sup⁡U∈Usup⁡z∈K U(z)≤M.\sup_{U\in\mathcal{U}} \sup_{z \in K}\, U\p{z} \leq M.U∈Usup​z∈Ksup​U(z)≤M.

You may use Harnack's inequality for the disk without proving it, provided you state it correctly.
Solution.

We first state Harnack's inequality: Let uuu be a non-negative harmonic function on the open disk D(z0,R)D\p{z_0, R}D(z0​,R). Then for z∈D(z0,R)z \in D\p{z_0, R}z∈D(z0​,R),

0≤u(z)≤(RR−∣z−z0∣)2u(z0).0 \leq u\p{z} \leq \p{\frac{R}{R - \abs{z - z_0}}}^2 u\p{z_0}.0≤u(z)≤(R−∣z−z0​∣R​)2u(z0​).

Let δ=12d(K,Ωc)>0\delta = \frac{1}{2}d\p{K, \Omega^\comp} > 0δ=21​d(K,Ωc)>0, since KKK and Ωc\Omega^\compΩc are disjoint closed sets. Since KKK is totally bounded, this implies that we can cover KKK with finitely many balls B(z1,δ),…,B(zn,δ)B\p{z_1, \delta}, \ldots, B\p{z_n, \delta}B(z1​,δ),…,B(zn​,δ). By construction, the corresponding closed balls B(zj,δ)‾⊆Ω\cl{B\p{z_j, \delta}} \subseteq \OmegaB(zj​,δ)​⊆Ω also. Set E=⋃j=1nB(zj,δ)‾⊆ΩE = \bigcup_{j=1}^n \cl{B\p{z_j, \delta}} \subseteq \OmegaE=⋃j=1n​B(zj​,δ)​⊆Ω. Since EEE is a finite union of compact balls, EEE is itself compact and has finitely many connected components (it has at most NNN, one for each ball). Hence, we may connect all the components together with finitely many curves to form a new set FFF, since Ω\OmegaΩ is connected, hence path connected. Because FFF is a union of a compact set EEE and finitely many compact curves, FFF is also compact, and by construction, EEE is connected. Since K⊆FK \subseteq FK⊆F, if we find an upper bound MMM for FFF, this gives us an upper bound on KKK. Thus, by replacing KKK with FFF, we may assume without loss of generality that KKK is a connected, compact set in Ω\OmegaΩ.

With δ\deltaδ as before, compactness implies that we can cover KKK with finitely many balls B(z1,δ3),…,B(zN,δ3)B\p{z_1, \frac{\delta}{3}}, \ldots, B\p{z_N, \frac{\delta}{3}}B(z1​,3δ​),…,B(zN​,3δ​) such that B(zj,δ)⊆ΩB\p{z_j, \delta} \subseteq \OmegaB(zj​,δ)⊆Ω as well. By Harnack's inequality, for z∈B(zj,2δ3)z \in B\p{z_j, \frac{2\delta}{3}}z∈B(zj​,32δ​), we have

0≤u(z)≤(δδ−∣z−z0∣)2u(zj)≤(δδ−2δ3)2u(zj)=9u(zj)(1)\tag{1} 0 \leq u\p{z} \leq \p{\frac{\delta}{\delta - \abs{z - z_0}}}^2 u\p{z_j} \leq \p{\frac{\delta}{\delta - \frac{2\delta}{3}}}^2 u\p{z_j} = 9u\p{z_j}0≤u(z)≤(δ−∣z−z0​∣δ​)2u(zj​)≤(δ−32δ​δ​)2u(zj​)=9u(zj​)(1)

for any u∈Uu \in \mathcal{U}u∈U. Notice that these balls have the following property: if B(zj,δ3)∩B(zk,δ3)≠∅B\p{z_j, \frac{\delta}{3}} \cap B\p{z_k, \frac{\delta}{3}} \neq \emptysetB(zj​,3δ​)∩B(zk​,3δ​)=∅, then zk∈B(zj,2δ3)z_k \in B\p{z_j, \frac{2\delta}{3}}zk​∈B(zj​,32δ​). Indeed, given w∈B(zj,δ3)∩B(zk,δ3)w \in B\p{z_j, \frac{\delta}{3}} \cap B\p{z_k, \frac{\delta}{3}}w∈B(zj​,3δ​)∩B(zk​,3δ​), we have

∣zj−zk∣≤∣zj−w∣+∣w−zk∣<δ3+δ3=2δ3.\abs{z_j - z_k} \leq \abs{z_j - w} + \abs{w - z_k} < \frac{\delta}{3} + \frac{\delta}{3} = \frac{2\delta}{3}.∣zj​−zk​∣≤∣zj​−w∣+∣w−zk​∣<3δ​+3δ​=32δ​.

Now let z∈Kz \in Kz∈K and let γ\gammaγ be a curve in KKK connecting zzz and z0z_0z0​. Then γ\gammaγ traverses through the B(zj,δ3)B\p{z_j, \frac{\delta}{3}}B(zj​,3δ​) in some order. Let A={wj}j⊆{z1,…,zN}A = \set{w_j}_j \subseteq \set{z_1, \ldots, z_N}A={wj​}j​⊆{z1​,…,zN​} be the sequence of the centers of these balls, which is finite since γ\gammaγ is compact and these balls cover γ\gammaγ. For notation, let ∣A∣=M\abs{A} = M∣A∣=M.

Notice that B(wj,δ3)∩B(wj+1,δ3)≠∅B\p{w_j, \frac{\delta}{3}} \cap B\p{w_{j+1}, \frac{\delta}{3}} \neq \emptysetB(wj​,3δ​)∩B(wj+1​,3δ​)=∅ for all 1≤j<M1 \leq j < M1≤j<M. Indeed, because j<Mj < Mj<M, there exists t0t_0t0​ so that ∣γ(t0)−wj∣=δ3\abs{\gamma\p{t_0} - w_j} = \frac{\delta}{3}∣γ(t0​)−wj​∣=3δ​, i.e., a time when γ\gammaγ leaves B(wj,δ3)B\p{w_j, \frac{\delta}{3}}B(wj​,3δ​) and enters B(wj+1,δ3)B\p{w_{j+1}, \frac{\delta}{3}}B(wj+1​,3δ​). Since B(wj+1,δ3)B\p{w_{j+1}, \frac{\delta}{3}}B(wj+1​,3δ​), there exists an open neighborhood γ(t0)∈U⊆B(wj+1,δ3)\gamma\p{t_0} \in U \subseteq B\p{w_{j+1}, \frac{\delta}{3}}γ(t0​)∈U⊆B(wj+1​,3δ​). Since γ(t0)\gamma\p{t_0}γ(t0​) is a boundary point of B(wj,δ3)B\p{w_j, \frac{\delta}{3}}B(wj​,3δ​), this means that U∩B(wj,δ3)≠∅U \cap B\p{w_j, \frac{\delta}{3}} \neq \emptysetU∩B(wj​,3δ​)=∅, and so B(wj,δ3)∩B(wj+1,δ3)≠∅B\p{w_j, \frac{\delta}{3}} \cap B\p{w_{j+1}, \frac{\delta}{3}} \neq \emptysetB(wj​,3δ​)∩B(wj+1​,3δ​)=∅, as claimed.

Next, we need to remove duplicates from AAA. We do this as follows: let mmm be the first index so that wm=wkw_m = w_kwm​=wk​ for some 1≤k<m1 \leq k < m1≤k<m, and remove wk+1,…,wmw_{k+1}, \ldots, w_mwk+1​,…,wm​ from AAA. Notice that

B(wk,δ3)∩B(wm+1,δ3)=B(wm,δ3)∩B(wm+1,δ3)≠∅,B\p{w_k, \frac{\delta}{3}} \cap B\p{w_{m+1}, \frac{\delta}{3}} = B\p{w_m, \frac{\delta}{3}} \cap B\p{w_{m+1}, \frac{\delta}{3}} \neq \emptyset,B(wk​,3δ​)∩B(wm+1​,3δ​)=B(wm​,3δ​)∩B(wm+1​,3δ​)=∅,

so the property we described before still holds with wk+1,…,wmw_{k+1}, \ldots, w_mwk+1​,…,wm​ removed. Renumber AAA so that wk+ℓ=wm+ℓw_{k+\ell} = w_{m+\ell}wk+ℓ​=wm+ℓ​ for ℓ≥1\ell \geq 1ℓ≥1.

By induction, we may repeat this process, and this must terminate after finitely many steps since AAA is finite. When this occurs, AAA has no more duplicates, which implies that ∣A∣=M≤N\abs{A} = M \leq N∣A∣=M≤N. To complete the proof, observe that wj+1∈B(wj,2δ3)w_{j+1} \in B\p{w_j, \frac{2\delta}{3}}wj+1​∈B(wj​,32δ​) by construction, and so by (1),

0≤u(wj+1)≤9u(wj).0 \leq u\p{w_{j+1}} \leq 9u\p{w_j}.0≤u(wj+1​)≤9u(wj​).

By construction, wM=zw_M = zwM​=z and w1=z0w_1 = z_0w1​=z0​, and by induction, we conclude that

u(z)=u(wM)≤9Mu(w1)=9Mu(z0)≤9N.u\p{z} = u\p{w_M} \leq 9^Mu\p{w_1} = 9^Mu\p{z_0} \leq 9^N.u(z)=u(wM​)≤9Mu(w1​)=9Mu(z0​)≤9N.

Since z∈Kz \in Kz∈K was chosen arbitrarily, we see that

sup⁡u∈Usup⁡z∈K u(z)≤9N,\sup_{u \in \mathcal{U}} \sup_{z \in K}\, u\p{z} \leq 9^N,u∈Usup​z∈Ksup​u(z)≤9N,

which completes the proof.
